Chapter 9: Consequential Loss Insurance

Introduction

Consequential Loss Insurance, also known as Business Interruption Insurance, compensates for trading losses arising from business stoppage due to a fire. This chapter covers features like indemnity, insured sum, and policy structure, including operative clauses, schedules, definitions, and conditions.

A. Trading Losses

1. Types of Trading Losses

  • Net Profit: The margin of income over expenses.
  • Standing Charges: Fixed overhead expenses such as rent, taxes, and salaries.
  • Increased Cost of Working: Extra costs to maintain operations, such as temporary premises or hired equipment.

The subject matter of fire insurance is material property, while profits insurance focuses on the earning capacity of the property.

2. Basis of Loss of Profit Insurance

  • Turnover: The money earned from goods sold and services rendered.
  • Loss of profit is measured by reductions in turnover.

3. Measure of Indemnity

  • Calculated by applying the rate of gross profit to the reduction in turnover during the indemnity period.
  • Example: A 30% gross profit rate applied to a turnover reduction of Rs. 25,00,000 results in Rs. 7,50,000 trading loss.

4. Indemnity Period

  • Selected based on the time required to reinstate operations, typically 3 months to 3 years.
  • The indemnity period starts after the damage and may extend beyond the policy period.

5. Sum Insured

  • Computed from trading and profit-and-loss accounts.
  • Includes net profit and standing charges as gross profit.
  • Adjusted based on expected growth and chosen indemnity period.

B. The Consequential Loss Policy

1. Operative Clause

  • States that damage to property must interrupt business for the policy to respond.
  • Losses are paid based on provisions in the policy specification.

2. Material Damage Proviso

  • Requires a valid fire policy for consequential loss claims.
  • Ensures restoration of damaged property, minimizing claim outgo.

3. Schedule and Specification

  • Schedule: Includes insured details, premises, sum insured, indemnity period, and premium.
  • Specification: Lists items insured, definitions, and formulas for liability computation.

4. Key Definitions

  • Net Profit: Income remaining after all expenses, including depreciation.
  • Gross Profit: Net profit plus insured standing charges.
  • Turnover: Revenue from trading activities.

5. Adjustment Clause

  • Adjusts figures for trends or special circumstances to ensure fair indemnity.
  • Example: Increased turnover due to new machinery is considered in loss calculation.

C. Policy Conditions

1. Business Continuity

  • The policy ceases if the business is permanently discontinued or altered.

2. Claims Procedure

  • Notice must be given promptly after damage.
  • Documentation, including vouchers and invoices, must be provided.

3. Exclusions

  • Costs like litigation, goodwill loss, and penalties are not covered.
  • Preparation of fire and consequential loss claims is excluded unless covered under a special clause.

D. Claims Computation

The claim amount is calculated based on:

  • Reduction in turnover adjusted for trends.
  • Gross profit rate applied to turnover reduction.
  • Additional costs incurred to reduce turnover loss.
  • Adjustments for under-insurance and saved standing charges.

Example

  • Gross profit insured: Rs. 3,00,000
  • Standard turnover: Rs. 10,00,000
  • Reduction in turnover: Rs. 6,00,000
  • Gross profit rate: 30%
  • Claim payable: Rs. 1,80,000

Conclusion

Consequential Loss Insurance provides comprehensive coverage for trading losses due to business interruption. It emphasizes accurate sum insured, proper documentation, and adherence to policy conditions to ensure fair compensation.
